channel.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
channel.description:
Well, i've just recently I had a thought, and then, it came into a plan. I have an Object decompressing tool, which decompresses ALL object's from every Map-region on the server. For each Object that is spawned, a file will be created in a certain folder, with the Object ID, the Type of object, and the coordinates the object was spawned over created in the file.
Then I was thinking...
Using an Anti-Noclipping base that i've created, I found that instead of reading off objects, and their coordinates through a single file, I can do it through [b]Several[/b] files.
So, if this is the case...
I can use the decompresser tool, extract all objects that are spawned into files, with their IDs, type, and coordinates in those files, and then use the Anti-Noclipping base to read the files, and just simply use a code to declare if walking over those coordinates of which objects that are spawned, to stop the NPC before it walks over the said objects, creating an Anti-Noclipping system
This would be a perfect thing to add to a server. If this works, it may be one of the best updates to add to a server, and may be very helpful to some.
I'm posting it here, because I want to discuss it with the MoparScape community. I want to hear about what you think about this plan? Would this be something worth trying?
Just imagine it...

item.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Implement the A* pathfinding algorithm, keep track of un-walkable tiles/object locations cached into region objects. Load the data for the region when a player enters that region, and release the reference to the region when it isn’t being used. This way, you save memory as you only have what you need in memory. Take the initial point and the last point that the client sends you in a walking packet as point A and point B. Plug it into your pathfinder, generate the path, and make the player walk it.

Read full topic

item.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
item.dc:creator: @QuestMaster_2K10 QuestMaster 2K10
item.description:
@QuestMaster_2K10 wrote:

[quote=“Canownueazy, post:5, topic:365599”]You also need to understand about different object types.

Type 22 is walkable except if it’s on a sky height (1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, ect).

Type 0 is walkable but cannot move further until the entity they are following goes in a specific direction. If you were to at a wall facing West towards your follower, the follower needs to be north, south, east, north east, south east in order for you to move.

It’s a very long process which requires a lot of logic.

Here’s what I’ve done so far: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zMg77KqG5BY

And heres one thats older but shows more: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j0Olv5_Ob1I[/quote]

Yes, i’m very familiar with Object types, i’m not stupid.

Read full topic

item.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
item.dc:creator: @Canownueazy Canownueazy
item.description:
@Canownueazy wrote:

You also need to understand about different object types.

Type 22 is walkable except if it’s on a sky height (1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, ect).

Type 0 is walkable but cannot move further until the entity they are following goes in a specific direction. If you were to at a wall facing West towards your follower, the follower needs to be north, south, east, north east, south east in order for you to move.

It’s a very long process which requires a lot of logic.

Here’s what I’ve done so far: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zMg77KqG5BY

And heres one thats older but shows more: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j0Olv5_Ob1I

Read full topic

item.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
item.dc:creator: @reverce reverce
item.description:
@reverce wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:3, topic:365599”]It would be a real memory hog to keep all the values available all the time. you also don’t really need to ‘decompress’ all the object definitions just the map file. Look at a 317 client how sending the walking queue works. it checks a map array to see if the location is reachable and then sends the queue if it is. one could simply use the same method in the server. However If you were to implement this only have the data available for regions ‘in use’ by players. the other regions should just hold nothing until they become ‘in use’. When an new region becomes in use you should take the time to load the necessary information before telling the client that entered the region that everything is fully loaded. (Runescape 317 had a packet for this I would assume the new version do as well)

‘in use region’ - when a client is in the region all other regions should be considered not in use with the exception of the wilderness which should be the clients regions and surrounding 8 blocks as many of the players will be running around quickly and a region loading delay could cause a unfair death to a player.[/quote]

Very hard explenation. But from the part I understand its true.

Read full topic

item.title: RSPS - [%100-Complete] Anti-Noclip
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

It would be a real memory hog to keep all the values available all the time. you also don’t really need to ‘decompress’ all the object definitions just the map file. Look at a 317 client how sending the walking queue works. it checks a map array to see if the location is reachable and then sends the queue if it is. one could simply use the same method in the server. However If you were to implement this only have the data available for regions ‘in use’ by players. the other regions should just hold nothing until they become ‘in use’. When an new region becomes in use you should take the time to load the necessary information before telling the client that entered the region that everything is fully loaded. (Runescape 317 had a packet for this I would assume the new version do as well)

‘in use region’ - when a client is in the region all other regions should be considered not in use with the exception of the wilderness which should be the clients regions and surrounding 8 blocks as many of the players will be running around quickly and a region loading delay could cause a unfair death to a player.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mr_Bobby Mr. Bobby
item.description:
@Mr_Bobby wrote:

im pretty sure some servers have this, well maybe not this way but I know battlescape has clipped npcs and I think one called emps scape has this, but anyways you should do it and if it works, release it for hundreds of people to leech with absolutely no credits to you what so ever

Read full topic
